Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is aimed at investigation of collective behavior of large groups of individual agents that is typified by swarming. In addition to its intrinsic scientific value, understanding collective behavior observed in nature (such as in flocks of birds and schools of fish) is expected to facilitate the ability to control technological swarms in the form of nanoparticles delivering drugs or micro-robots performing assemblies and conducting searches. There is a variety of models that provide superficially similar output, that is, they all generate some sort of collective motion. However, there is a lack of studies that distinguish among swarming models and determine their relevance with respect to experimental observations. This project develops a bridge between different mathematical tools to describe swarming behavior and experimentally relevant measures of such behavior in application fields ranging from biology to robotics and from marketing to opinion formation.

For many common mathematical models, characterizations of swarms are elementary (for example, flocking or milling) and are based on simple global quantities (that is, average velocity or angular momentum). In contrast, this project focuses on more complex observables unveiling key attributes of swarms and swarming models. For instance, the speed of information propagation is crucial in swarming to avoid obstacles or predators and can be characterized through the analysis of different types of traveling waves. Similarly, interaction with boundaries and other swarms generate internal excitations in the form of standing waves. Connecting swarming behavior and observables requires investigating both micro- and macro-scales. Therefore, this project will combine tools from information theory and statistical physics (micro-models) with the analysis of partial differential equations (macro-models).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this award was to investigate swarming behavior (e.g. flocking, herding) from a macroscopic viewpoint. In other words, we asked whether 'fluid type' model could be used to describe collective behavior.  Since there exists a multitude of swarming models, it is critical to better characterize their dynamics, especially if we want to confront swarming models with experimental data. There are several ways to address this challenge, we briefly describe three different directions we investigated during this award.
  First, we have analyzed using macroscopic models traffic flow for both pedestrians and ants. Traffic models are usually characterized by the so-called fundamental diagram which relates density and flow. The fundamental diagram has usually a bell-shape: it increases at low-density (free flow) and decreases at high-density (traffic jam). Various collaborations has allowed us to measure such fundamental diagram experimentally for both pedestrian and ants dynamics. To our surprise, the fundamental diagram for ants' dynamics did not decay at high-density: ants are still able to maintain a high flux even we double the density. This observation raises the question about the mechanisms at play at the microscopic level. How do ants' behavior differ from pedestrian in order to maintain such efficiency at high density? We are currently working on various agent-based models (i.e. microscopic models) to further infer the mechanisms allowing ants to avoid getting stuck in traffic jam.
  Then, from a theoretical point of view, we investigated the macroscopic limit of novel type of swarming models. For instance, motivated by experiments on brain-tumor, we derived the macroscopic limit of a diffusive model for cancer cells coupled with a birth process (modeling proliferation). In the asymptotic limit of non-overlapping (cells cannot occupy the same space), we have shown that the microscopic model leads to a free boundary problem (Hele-Shaw type). Thus, the dynamics at large scales is solely characterized by the behavior of the boundary of the tumor. This work has further instigated new developments in the rigorous derivation of Hele-Shaw type equation from particle systems (on-going work with Prof. Mellet).
  Finally, we explored flocking models in a new setting, namely working with boundary conditions. Boundary conditions are ubiquitous in nature (e.g. the ground for flocking), but they are usually ignore in swarming models (e.g. no boundary or periodic boundary conditions). We explored in two papers the effects of reflexive and diffusive boundary conditions. We showed for instance that bounded domain tend to form vortex formations and such large scale formation can be captured using the corresponding macroscopic model (Partial Differential Equations).

In total, this award has led to  publications and two workshops were organized along the idea of the grant (2015 and 2018 at ASU). Several students were part of the projects: 3 PhD students graduated (Andee Thatcher 2016, Kirk Kayser 2018, Sarah El Jamous 2019) and 6 students have started their PhD with work related to this grant (Luke Baker, Fei Cao, Nicholas Cortez, Camille Moyer, Atta Ullah, Dylan Weber).
 This work has also an impact outside the mathematical community. After we presented our work on cancer modeling with a collaborator Prof. Lowenstein (univ. Michigan) at the ASCB Annual Meeting in 2015, we were selected to participate in a news media event. This press media conference led to several articles in popular science magazines (science news, science daily, EurekAlert). More recently, our work on traffic flow for ants' dynamics have also appealed to a more general public (ants are always popular). We conducted two podcast interviews for scientific magazines (60-second science podcasts, KJZZ news radio).
